Problem Overview

In this problem, students use the context of sharing smoothie bars in order to explore and analyze the equivalence of ratios and relationships between equivalent ratios. Students will use a tape diagram for solving ratio tasks by creating equivalent ratios and ratio reasoning.

Help students understand what segmented smoothie bars are, and help them understand the unequal sharing context. Make sure they understand that they can cut the segments into smaller pieces as part of their work.

Make sure students understand that for each questions, and each part of a questions, they start with a new smoothie bar and so will need to draw new diagrams.

Arc of Learning: Exploration, Analysis

Standards: See your state alignment chart.

NWDYK?

How can visual representations, like the bars that represent smoothie bars, help you think about equivalent ratios? How are these bars useful in solving problems?

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Introduce the use of tape diagrams via smoothie bars for solving ratio tasks by creating equivalent ratios and ratio reasoning.

Begin to notice

  • the smoothie bars (tape diagrams) make it easy to visualize the multiplicative relationship described by a ratio;
  • the smoothie bar partitions can be further partitioned when more pieces are needed to find equivalent ratios with factional parts of a segment (like Sofia and Dembe in the Initial Challenge);
  • the smoothie bars can be easily duplicated to created additional equivalent ratios; and
  • the connections between patterns found in ratio tables for equivalent ratios and the concrete representations of the ratios using the smoothie bars.
